shortDefinition: Software tool that automates installing, updating, and removing programs.
longDefinition: A package manager is a tool that automates the process of installing, upgrading, configuring, and removing software packages. It handles dependencies (other packages your software needs to work), connects to repositories to download software, and keeps track of what's installed on your system. Different Linux distributions use different package managers: APT for Debian/Ubuntu, DNF for Fedora, Pacman for Arch Linux.
examples: APT - Used by Debian, Ubuntu, Mint

seo.title: What is a Package Manager? | Linux Software Management
